They mar my path.
    They promote my destruction
    without anyone’s help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As through a wide breach they come.
    They roll themselves in amid the ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrors have turned on me.
    They chase my honor as the wind.
    My welfare has passed away as a cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now my soul is poured out within me.
    Days of affliction have taken hold of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the night season my bones are pierced in me,
    and the pains that gnaw me take no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My garment is disfigured by great force.
    It binds me about as the collar of my tunic.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has cast me into the mire.
    I have become like dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cry to you, and you do not answer me.
    I stand up, and you gaze at me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have turned to be cruel to me.
    With the might of your hand you persecute me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You lift me up to the wind, and drive me with it.
    You dissolve me in the storm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I know that you will bring me to death,
    to the house appointed for all living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“However doesn’t one stretch out a hand in his fall?
    Or in his calamity therefore cry for help?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Didn’t I weep for him who was in trouble?
    Wasn’t my soul grieved for the needy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I looked for good, then evil came.
    When I waited for light, darkness came.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My heart is troubled, and doesn’t rest.
    Days of affliction have come on me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I go mourning without the sun.
    I stand up in the assembly, and cry for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am a brother to jackals,
    and a companion to ostriches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My skin grows black and peels from me.
    My bones are burned with heat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore my harp has turned to mourning,
    and my pipe into the voice of those who weep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I made a covenant with my eyes;
    how then should I look lustfully at a young woman?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what is the portion from God above,
    and the heritage from the Almighty on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it not calamity to the unrighteous,
    and disaster to the workers of iniquity?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doesn’t he see my ways,
    and count all my steps?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have walked with falsehood,
    and my foot has hurried to deceit
speaker: Narrator

text:
(let me be weighed in an even balance,
    that God may know my integrity);
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
then let me sow, and let another eat.
    Yes, let the produce of my field be rooted out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my heart has been enticed to a woman,
    and I have laid wait at my neighbor’s door,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my wife grind for another,
    and let others sleep with her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For that would be a heinous crime.
    Yes, it would be an iniquity to be punished by the judges,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for it is a fire that consumes to destruction,
    and would root out all my increase.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have despised the cause of my male servant
    or of my female servant,
    when they contended with me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
what then will I do when God rises up?
    When he visits, what will I answer him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Didn’t he who made me in the womb make him?
    Didn’t one fashion us in the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have withheld the poor from their desire,
    or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or have eaten my morsel alone,
    and the fatherless has not eaten of it
speaker: Narrator

text:
(no, from my youth he grew up with me as with a father,
    I have guided her from my mother’s womb);
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have seen any perish for want of clothing,
    or that the needy had no covering;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if his heart hasn’t blessed me,
    if he hasn’t been warmed with my sheep’s fleece;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have lifted up my hand against the fatherless,
    because I saw my help in the gate;
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my shoulder fall from the shoulder blade,
    and my arm be broken from the bone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For calamity from God is a terror to me.
    Because of his majesty, I can do nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have made gold my hope,
    and have said to the fine gold, ‘You are my confidence;’
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have rejoiced because my wealth was great,
    and because my hand had gotten much;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have seen the sun when it shined,
    or the moon moving in splendor,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and my heart has been secretly enticed,
    and my hand threw a kiss from my mouth;
speaker: Narrator

text:
this also would be an iniquity to be punished by the judges,
    for I would have denied the God who is above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have rejoiced at the destruction of him who hated me,
    or lifted up myself when evil found him
speaker: Narrator

text:
(I have certainly not allowed my mouth to sin
    by asking his life with a curse);
speaker: Narrator

text:
if the men of my tent have not said,
    ‘Who can find one who has not been filled with his meat?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
(the foreigner has not camped in the street,
    but I have opened my doors to the traveler);
speaker: Narrator

text:
if like Adam I have covered my transgressions,
    by hiding my iniquity in my heart,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because I feared the great multitude,
    and the contempt of families terrified me,
    so that I kept silence, and didn’t go out of the door—
speaker: Narrator

text:
oh that I had one to hear me!
    Behold, here is my signature! Let the Almighty answer me!
    Let the accuser write my indictment!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely I would carry it on my shoulder,
    and I would bind it to me as a crown.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would declare to him the number of my steps.
    I would go near to him like a prince.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If my land cries out against me,
    and its furrows weep together;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have eaten its fruits without money,
    or have caused its owners to lose their life,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: So these three men ceased to answer Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the wrath of Elihu the son of Barachel, the Buzite, of the family of Ram, was kindled against Job. His wrath was kindled because he justified himself rather than God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also his wrath was kindled against his three friends, because they had found no answer, and yet had condemned Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elihu had waited to speak to Job, because they were older than he.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouth of these three men, his wrath was kindled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite answered,
“I am young, and you are very old.
    Therefore I held back, and didn’t dare show you my opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, ‘Days should speak,
    and multitude of years should teach wisdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But there is a spirit in man,
    and the Spirit of the Almighty gives them understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not the great who are wise,
    nor the aged who understand justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I said, ‘Listen to me;
    I also will show my opinion.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, I waited for your words,
    and I listened for your reasoning,
    while you searched out what to say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, I gave you my full attention,
    but there was no one who convinced Job,
    or who answered his words, among you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Beware lest you say, ‘We have found wisdom.
    God may refute him, not man;’
speaker: Narrator

text:
for he has not directed his words against me;
    neither will I answer him with your speeches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They are amazed. They answer no more.
    They don’t have a word to say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall I wait, because they don’t speak,
    because they stand still, and answer no more?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I also will answer my part,
    and I also will show my opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I am full of words.
    The spirit within me constrains me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, my breast is as wine which has no vent;
    like new wineskins it is ready to burst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will speak, that I may be refreshed.
    I will open my lips and answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please don’t let me respect any man’s person,
    neither will I give flattering titles to any man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I don’t know how to give flattering titles,
    or else my Maker would soon take me away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“However, Job, please hear my speech,
    and listen to all my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See now, I have opened my mouth.
    My tongue has spoken in my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My words will utter the uprightness of my heart.
    That which my lips know they will speak sincerely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Spirit of God has made me,
    and the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you can, answer me.
    Set your words in order before me, and stand up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, I am toward God even as you are.
    I am also formed out of the clay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, my terror will not make you afraid,
    neither will my pressure be heavy on you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely you have spoken in my hearing,
    I have heard the voice of your words, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I am clean, without disobedience.
    I am innocent, neither is there iniquity in me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, he finds occasions against me.
    He counts me for his enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He puts my feet in the stocks.
    He marks all my paths.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, I will answer you. In this you are not just,
    for God is greater than man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you strive against him,
    because he doesn’t give account of any of his matters?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God speaks once,
    yes twice, though man pays no attention.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In a dream, in a vision of the night,
    when deep sleep falls on men,
    in slumbering on the bed,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then he opens the ears of men,
    and seals their instruction,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that he may withdraw man from his purpose,
    and hide pride from man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He keeps back his soul from the pit,
    and his life from perishing by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He is chastened also with pain on his bed,
    with continual strife in his bones,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that his life abhors bread,
    and his soul dainty food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His flesh is so consumed away that it can’t be seen.
    His bones that were not seen stick out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, his soul draws near to the pit,
    and his life to the destroyers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If there is beside him an angel,
    an interpreter, one among a thousand,
    to show to man what is right for him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then God is gracious to him, and says,
    ‘Deliver him from going down to the pit,
    I have found a ransom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
His flesh will be fresher than a child’s.
    He returns to the days of his youth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He prays to God, and he is favorable to him,
    so that he sees his face with joy.
    He restores to man his righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sings before men, and says,
    ‘I have sinned, and perverted that which was right,
    and it didn’t profit me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has redeemed my soul from going into the pit.
    My life will see the light.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, God does all these things,
    twice, yes three times, with a man,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to bring back his soul from the pit,
    that he may be enlightened with the light of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mark well, Job, and listen to me.
    Hold your peace, and I will speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have anything to say, answer me.
    Speak, for I desire to justify you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If not, listen to me.
    Hold your peace, and I will teach you wisdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover Elihu answered,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Hear my words, you wise men.
    Give ear to me, you who have knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the ear tries words,
    as the palate tastes food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us choose for us that which is right.
    Let us know among ourselves what is good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For Job has said, ‘I am righteous,
    God has taken away my right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Notwithstanding my right I am considered a liar.
    My wound is incurable, though I am without disobedience.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
What man is like Job,
    who drinks scorn like water,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who goes in company with the workers of iniquity,
    and walks with wicked men?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he has said, ‘It profits a man nothing
    that he should delight himself with God.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore listen to me, you men of understanding:
    far be it from God, that he should do wickedness,
    from the Almighty, that he should commit iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the work of a man he will render to him,
    and cause every man to find according to his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes surely, God will not do wickedly,
    neither will the Almighty pervert justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who put him in charge of the earth?
    Or who has appointed him over the whole world?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he set his heart on himself,
    if he gathered to himself his spirit and his breath,
speaker: Narrator

text:
all flesh would perish together,
    and man would turn again to dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If now you have understanding, hear this.
    Listen to the voice of my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should even one who hates justice govern?
    Will you condemn him who is righteous and mighty,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who says to a king, ‘Vile!’
    or to nobles, ‘Wicked!’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t respect the persons of princes,
    nor respect the rich more than the poor,
    for they all are the work of his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In a moment they die, even at midnight.
    The people are shaken and pass away.
    The mighty are taken away without a hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For his eyes are on the ways of a man.
    He sees all his goings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no darkness, nor thick gloom,
    where the workers of iniquity may hide themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he doesn’t need to consider a man further,
    that he should go before God in judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He breaks mighty men in pieces in ways past finding out,
    and sets others in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore he takes knowledge of their works.
    He overturns them in the night, so that they are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He strikes them as wicked men
    in the open sight of others;
speaker: Narrator

text:
because they turned away from following him,
    and wouldn’t pay attention to any of his ways,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that they caused the cry of the poor to come to him.
    He heard the cry of the afflicted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he gives quietness, who then can condemn?
    When he hides his face, who then can see him?
    He is over a nation or a man alike,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that the godless man may not reign,
    that there be no one to ensnare the people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For has any said to God,
    ‘I am guilty, but I will not offend any more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Teach me that which I don’t see.
    If I have done iniquity, I will do it no more’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall his recompense be as you desire, that you refuse it?
    For you must choose, and not I.
    Therefore speak what you know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Men of understanding will tell me,
    yes, every wise man who hears me:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Job speaks without knowledge.
    His words are without wisdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I wish that Job were tried to the end,
    because of his answering like wicked men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he adds rebellion to his sin.
    He claps his hands among us,
    and multiplies his words against God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover Elihu answered,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you think this to be your right,
    or do you say, ‘My righteousness is more than God’s,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
that you ask, ‘What advantage will it be to you?
    What profit will I have, more than if I had sinned?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will answer you,
    and your companions with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look to the skies, and see.
    See the skies, which are higher than you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have sinned, what effect do you have against him?
    If your transgressions are multiplied, what do you do to him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are righteous, what do you give him?
    Or what does he receive from your hand?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your wickedness may hurt a man as you are,
    and your righteousness may profit a son of man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“By reason of the multitude of oppressions they cry out.
    They cry for help by reason of the arm of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But no one says, ‘Where is God my Maker,
    who gives songs in the night,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who teaches us more than the animals of the earth,
    and makes us wiser than the birds of the sky?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
There they cry, but no one answers,
    because of the pride of evil men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely God will not hear an empty cry,
    neither will the Almighty regard it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much less when you say you don’t see him.
    The cause is before him, and you wait for him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now, because he has not visited in his anger,
    neither does he greatly regard arrogance,
speaker: Narrator

text:
therefore Job opens his mouth with empty talk,
    and he multiplies words without knowledge.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu also continued, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Bear with me a little, and I will show you;
    for I still have something to say on God’s behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will get my knowledge from afar,
    and will ascribe righteousness to my Maker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For truly my words are not false.
    One who is perfect in knowledge is with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, God is mighty, and doesn’t despise anyone.
    He is mighty in strength of understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t preserve the life of the wicked,
    but gives justice to the afflicted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t withdraw his eyes from the righteous,
    but with kings on the throne,
    he sets them forever, and they are exalted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If they are bound in fetters,
    and are taken in the cords of afflictions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then he shows them their work,
    and their transgressions, that they have behaved themselves proudly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He also opens their ears to instruction,
    and commands that they return from iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If they listen and serve him,
    they will spend their days in prosperity,
    and their years in pleasures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if they don’t listen, they will perish by the sword;
    they will die without knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But those who are godless in heart lay up anger.
    They don’t cry for help when he binds them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They die in youth.
    Their life perishes among the unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He delivers the afflicted by their affliction,
    and opens their ear in oppression.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, he would have allured you out of distress,
    into a wide place, where there is no restriction.
    That which is set on your table would be full of fatness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But you are full of the judgment of the wicked.
    Judgment and justice take hold of you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t let riches entice you to wrath,
    neither let the great size of a bribe turn you aside.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Would your wealth sustain you in distress,
    or all the might of your strength?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t desire the night,
    when people are cut off in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take heed, don’t regard iniquity;
    for you have chosen this rather than affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, God is exalted in his power.
    Who is a teacher like him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has prescribed his way for him?
    Or who can say, ‘You have committed unrighteousness’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Remember that you magnify his work,
    about which men have sung.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All men have looked on it.
    Man sees it afar off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, God is great, and we don’t know him.
    The number of his years is unsearchable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he draws up the drops of water,
    which distill in rain from his vapor,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which the skies pour down
    and which drop on man abundantly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, can anyone understand the spreading of the clouds
    and the thunderings of his pavilion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, he spreads his light around him.
    He covers the bottom of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For by these he judges the people.
    He gives food in abundance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He covers his hands with the lightning,
    and commands it to strike the mark.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its noise tells about him,
    and the livestock also, concerning the storm that comes up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yes, at this my heart trembles,
    and is moved out of its place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear, oh, hear the noise of his voice,
    the sound that goes out of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sends it out under the whole sky,
    and his lightning to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After it a voice roars.
    He thunders with the voice of his majesty.
    He doesn’t hold back anything when his voice is heard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God thunders marvelously with his voice.
    He does great things, which we can’t comprehend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he says to the snow, ‘Fall on the earth,’
    likewise to the shower of rain,
    and to the showers of his mighty rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He seals up the hand of every man,
    that all men whom he has made may know it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the animals take cover,
    and remain in their dens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of its room comes the storm,
    and cold out of the north.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the breath of God, ice is given,
    and the width of the waters is frozen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, he loads the thick cloud with moisture.
    He spreads abroad the cloud of his lightning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is turned around by his guidance,
    that they may do whatever he commands them
    on the surface of the habitable world,
speaker: Narrator

text:
whether it is for correction, or for his land,
    or for loving kindness, that he causes it to come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen to this, Job.
    Stand still, and consider the wondrous works of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know how God controls them,
    and causes the lightning of his cloud to shine?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know the workings of the clouds,
    the wondrous works of him who is perfect in knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You whose clothing is warm
    when the earth is still by reason of the south wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you, with him, spread out the sky,
    which is strong as a cast metal mirror?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Teach us what we will tell him,
    for we can’t make our case by reason of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it be told him that I would speak?
    Or should a man wish that he were swallowed up?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now men don’t see the light which is bright in the skies,
    but the wind passes, and clears them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of the north comes golden splendor.
    With God is awesome majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We can’t reach the Almighty.
    He is exalted in power.
    In justice and great righteousness, he will not oppress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore men revere him.
    He doesn’t regard any who are wise of heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh answered Job out of the whirlwind,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who is this who darkens counsel
    by words without knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Brace yourself like a man,
    for I will question you, then you answer me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where were you when I laid the foundations of the earth?
    Declare, if you have understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who determined its measures, if you know?
    Or who stretched the line on it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What were its foundations fastened on?
    Or who laid its cornerstone,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the morning stars sang together,
    and all the sons of God shouted for joy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Or who shut up the sea with doors,
    when it broke out of the womb,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I made clouds its garment,
    and wrapped it in thick darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
marked out for it my bound,
    set bars and doors,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said, ‘You may come here, but no further.
    Your proud waves shall be stopped here’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you commanded the morning in your days,
    and caused the dawn to know its place,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that it might take hold of the ends of the earth,
    and shake the wicked out of it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is changed as clay under the seal,
    and presented as a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the wicked, their light is withheld.
    The high arm is broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you entered into the springs of the sea?
    Or have you walked in the recesses of the deep?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have the gates of death been revealed to you?
    Or have you seen the gates of the shadow of death?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you comprehended the earth in its width?
    Declare, if you know it all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is the way to the dwelling of light?
    As for darkness, where is its place,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that you should take it to its bound,
    that you should discern the paths to its house?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely you know, for you were born then,
    and the number of your days is great!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you entered the storehouses of the snow,
    or have you seen the storehouses of the hail,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which I have reserved against the time of trouble,
    against the day of battle and war?
speaker: Narrator

text:
By what way is the lightning distributed,
    or the east wind scattered on the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has cut a channel for the flood water,
    or the path for the thunderstorm,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to cause it to rain on a land where there is no man,
    on the wilderness, in which there is no man,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to satisfy the waste and desolate ground,
    to cause the tender grass to grow?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does the rain have a father?
    Or who fathers the drops of dew?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whose womb did the ice come out of?
    Who has given birth to the gray frost of the sky?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waters become hard like stone,
    when the surface of the deep is frozen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you bind the cluster of the Pleiades,
    or loosen the cords of Orion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you lead the constellations out in their season?
    Or can you guide the Bear with her cubs?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know the laws of the heavens?
    Can you establish its dominion over the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you lift up your voice to the clouds,
    that abundance of waters may cover you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you send out lightnings, that they may go?
    Do they report to you, ‘Here we are’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has put wisdom in the inward parts?
    Or who has given understanding to the mind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can count the clouds by wisdom?
    Or who can pour out the containers of the sky,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the dust runs into a mass,
    and the clods of earth stick together?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you hunt the prey for the lioness,
    or satisfy the appetite of the young lions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when they crouch in their dens,
    and lie in wait in the thicket?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who provides for the raven his prey,
    when his young ones cry to God,
    and wander for lack of food?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you know the time when the mountain goats give birth?
    Do you watch when the doe bears fawns?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you count the months that they fulfill?
    Or do you know the time when they give birth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They bow themselves. They bear their young.
    They end their labor pains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their young ones become strong.
    They grow up in the open field.
    They go out, and don’t return again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who has set the wild donkey free?
    Or who has loosened the bonds of the swift donkey,
speaker: Narrator

text:
whose home I have made the wilderness,
    and the salt land his dwelling place?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He scorns the tumult of the city,
    neither does he hear the shouting of the driver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The range of the mountains is his pasture.
    He searches after every green thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will the wild ox be content to serve you?
    Or will he stay by your feeding trough?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you hold the wild ox in the furrow with his harness?
    Or will he till the valleys after you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you trust him, because his strength is great?
    Or will you leave to him your labor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you confide in him, that he will bring home your seed,
    and gather the grain of your threshing floor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The wings of the ostrich wave proudly,
    but are they the feathers and plumage of love?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For she leaves her eggs on the earth,
    warms them in the dust,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and forgets that the foot may crush them,
    or that the wild animal may trample them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She deals harshly with her young ones, as if they were not hers.
    Though her labor is in vain, she is without fear,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because God has deprived her of wisdom,
    neither has he imparted to her understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When she lifts up herself on high,
    she scorns the horse and his rider.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you given the horse might?
    Have you clothed his neck with a quivering mane?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you made him to leap as a locust?
    The glory of his snorting is awesome.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He paws in the valley, and rejoices in his strength.
    He goes out to meet the armed men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He mocks at fear, and is not dismayed,
    neither does he turn back from the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The quiver rattles against him,
    the flashing spear and the javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He eats up the ground with fierceness and rage,
    neither does he stand still at the sound of the trumpet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As often as the trumpet sounds he snorts, ‘Aha!’
    He smells the battle afar off,
    the thunder of the captains, and the shouting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is it by your wisdom that the hawk soars,
    and stretches her wings toward the south?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it at your command that the eagle mounts up,
    and makes his nest on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the cliff he dwells and makes his home,
    on the point of the cliff and the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From there he spies out the prey.
    His eyes see it afar off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His young ones also suck up blood.
    Where the slain are, there he is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover Yahweh answered Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Shall he who argues contend with the Almighty?
    He who argues with God, let him answer it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered Yahweh,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, I am of small account. What will I answer you?
    I lay my hand on my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have spoken once, and I will not answer;
    Yes, twice, but I will proceed no further.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh answered Job out of the whirlwind:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now brace yourself like a man.
    I will question you, and you will answer me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you even annul my judgment?
    Will you condemn me, that you may be justified?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or do you have an arm like God?
    Can you thunder with a voice like him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now deck yourself with excellency and dignity.
    Array yourself with honor and majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pour out the fury of your anger.
    Look at everyone who is proud, and bring him low.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at everyone who is proud, and humble him.
    Crush the wicked in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide them in the dust together.
    Bind their faces in the hidden place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will also admit to you
    that your own right hand can save you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“See now behemoth, which I made as well as you.
    He eats grass as an ox.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look now, his strength is in his thighs.
    His force is in the muscles of his belly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He moves his tail like a cedar.
    The sinews of his thighs are knit together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His bones are like tubes of bronze.
    His limbs are like bars of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is the chief of the ways of God.
    He who made him gives him his sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely the mountains produce food for him,
    where all the animals of the field play.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He lies under the lotus trees,
    in the covert of the reed, and the marsh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lotuses cover him with their shade.
    The willows of the brook surround him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, if a river overflows, he doesn’t tremble.
    He is confident, though the Jordan swells even to his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall any take him when he is on the watch,
    or pierce through his nose with a snare?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you draw out Leviathan with a fish hook,
    or press down his tongue with a cord?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you put a rope into his nose,
    or pierce his jaw through with a hook?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he make many petitions to you,
    or will he speak soft words to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he make a covenant with you,
    that you should take him for a servant forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you play with him as with a bird?
    Or will you bind him for your girls?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will traders barter for him?
    Will they part him among the merchants?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you fill his skin with barbed irons,
    or his head with fish spears?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lay your hand on him.
    Remember the battle, and do so no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, the hope of him is in vain.
    Won’t one be cast down even at the sight of him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
None is so fierce that he dare stir him up.
    Who then is he who can stand before me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has first given to me, that I should repay him?
    Everything under the heavens is mine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will not keep silence concerning his limbs,
    nor his mighty strength, nor his goodly frame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can strip off his outer garment?
    Who will come within his jaws?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can open the doors of his face?
    Around his teeth is terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strong scales are his pride,
    shut up together with a close seal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One is so near to another,
    that no air can come between them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are joined to one another.
    They stick together, so that they can’t be pulled apart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His sneezing flashes out light.
    His eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of his mouth go burning torches.
    Sparks of fire leap out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of his nostrils a smoke goes,
    as of a boiling pot over a fire of reeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His breath kindles coals.
    A flame goes out of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is strength in his neck.
    Terror dances before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The flakes of his flesh are joined together.
    They are firm on him.
    They can’t be moved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His heart is as firm as a stone,
    yes, firm as the lower millstone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he raises himself up, the mighty are afraid.
    They retreat before his thrashing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If one attacks him with the sword, it can’t prevail;
    nor the spear, the dart, nor the pointed shaft.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He counts iron as straw,
    and bronze as rotten wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The arrow can’t make him flee.
    Sling stones are like chaff to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Clubs are counted as stubble.
    He laughs at the rushing of the javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His undersides are like sharp potsherds,
    leaving a trail in the mud like a threshing sledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes the deep to boil like a pot.
    He makes the sea like a pot of ointment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes a path shine after him.
    One would think the deep had white hair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On earth there is not his equal,
    that is made without fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sees everything that is high.
    He is king over all the sons of pride.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered Yahweh:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I know that you can do all things,
    and that no purpose of yours can be restrained.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You asked, ‘Who is this who hides counsel without knowledge?’
    therefore I have uttered that which I didn’t understand,
    things too wonderful for me, which I didn’t know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You said, ‘Listen, now, and I will speak;
    I will question you, and you will answer me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I had heard of you by the hearing of the ear,
    but now my eye sees you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I abhor myself,
    and repent in dust and ashes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was so, that after Yahweh had spoken these words to Job, Yahweh said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “My wrath is kindled against you, and against your two friends; for you have not spoken of me the thing that is right, as my servant Job has.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, take to yourselves seven bulls and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering; and my servant Job shall pray for you, for I will accept him, that I not deal with you according to your folly. For you have not spoken of me the thing that is right, as my servant Job has.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite went and did what Yahweh commanded them, and Yahweh accepted Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh restored Job’s prosperity when he prayed for his friends. Yahweh gave Job twice as much as he had before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all his brothers, all his sisters, and all those who had been of his acquaintance before, came to him and ate bread with him in his house. They comforted him, and consoled him concerning all the evil that Yahweh had brought on him. Everyone also gave him a piece of money, and everyone a ring of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh blessed the latter end of Job more than his beginning. He had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, one thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand female donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had also seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called the name of the first, Jemimah; and the name of the second, Keziah; and the name of the third, Keren Happuch.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all the land were no women found so beautiful as the daughters of Job. Their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this Job lived one hundred forty years, and saw his sons, and his sons’ sons, to four generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Job died, being old and full of days.
speaker: Narrator
